content:
• Wednesday, October 16, 2013
  • USG

    USG guides Q3 below consensus; unveils JV in Asia, Australia, Middle East

    • USG Corp. (NYSE:USG) -5.9% AH after issuing downside guidance for Q3, seeing EPS of $0.21 vs. $0.29 analyst consensus and revenues of $925M vs. $936M consensus.
    • USG attributes the results, which are an improvement Y/Y, to better wallboard price and volume and positive operating results at L&W Supply, partially offset by higher SG&A expense as expected and lower profitability from its GTL shipping company due to timing of shipments in H2.
    • Also, USG announces a plasterboard and ceilings joint venture with Australian peer Boral Ltd.; in order to achieve a 50% interest in the JV, USG will pay Boral total cash payments of up to $575M.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:32 PM
  • NE

    Noble Corp. improves earnings, cuts downtime

    • Noble Corp. (NYSE:NE) +2.3% AH after more than doubling its Q3 earnings, as its rigs were kept busier and the rates paid for them improved.
    • The strong showing came on revenue of $1.07B, easily surpassing $884M million registered in the year-ago quarter; expenses also fell slightly, totaling $700M vs. $705M a year ago.
    • Downtime dropped to 4.6% from 5.2%, and NE saw drillships Noble Globetrotter II and Noble Don Taylor enter operations during the quarter.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:19 PM
  • WDC

    SanDisk issues solid Q4 guidance, shares +2.6% AH

    • SanDisk (SNDK) guides on its Q3 CC (webcast) for Q4 revenue of $1.65B-$1.725B; the midpoint is above a $1.67B. In addition, the NAND flash product vendor is guiding for a gross margin of 48%-50%, up from 39.9% a year earlier.
    • Thanks to a favorable NAND supply/demand balance and strong mobile device/SSD demand, Q3 gross margin was 50.1%, up from 46.7% in Q2 and 31% a year earlier. Strong margins helped fuel SanDisk's big EPS beat, as did $1.07B in buybacks ($1B of which came from an accelerated repurchase program).
    • As Micron recently indicated, NAND pricing is expected to soften a bit in Q4, but has been healthy thus far in 2013
    • Q3 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:46 PM

  • After-hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: SNDK +2.7%. NE +2.4%. AU +2.3%. ACRX +2.3%. VISN +2.1%.
    • Top losers: SCSS -25.9%. TPX -8.4%. USG -6.5%. IBM -5.8%. URI -4.7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:35 PM
  • XLNX

    Xilinx FQ3 guidance soft, Altera off in sympathy

    • Xilinx (NASDAQ:XLNX) expects FQ3 (Dec. quarter) revenue to be down 2% to up 2% Q/Q; the consensus is for a 1.4% increase.
    • FQ2 non-GAAP EPS (excludes a $0.09 litigation charge) was $0.58, beating a consensus of $0.53. Gross margin was 69.5%, +50 bps Q/Q and +350 bps Y/Y, and above guidance of 69%. FQ3 gross margin is expected to be around 69%.
    • Telecom/data center chip sales (43% of revenue) -3% Y/Y in FQ2 vs. -2% in FQ1. Industrial, aerospace, and defense (38% of revenue) was strong, +32% vs. +9%; broadcast, consumer, and automotive saw a turnaround, +17% vs. -5%.
    • R&D spend +12% Y/Y to $125M, SG&A +4% to $96.3M. $70M spent on buybacks.
    • XLNX -4.5% AH. Archrival ALTR -2.8%.
    • FQ2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:05 PM
  • SNBR

    Select Comfort plunges on Q3 miss, weak guidance

    • "Our execution was muted by a progressively more challenged macro-economic environment, resulting in performance below expectations," Select Comfort's (SCSS) Shelly Ibach says.
    • Whatever the case, investors don't like the company's quarter, as the shares are off 26% AH following a top and bottom line miss for Q3.
    • Operating margin fell 470 bps Y/Y for the period.
    • Outlook: FY13 EPS guidance is cut to $1.14-1.22 from $1.30-1.45. Management sees FQ4 EPS of $0.18-0.26 against consensus of $0.32/share. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:03 PM
  • NE

    Noble Corp beats by $0.15

    • Noble Corp (NYSE:NE): Q3 EPS of $0.85 beats by $0.15.
    • Revenue of $1.08B beats by $0.01B. Shares +1.1% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:03 PM
  • WDC

    SanDisk beats by $0.27, beats on revenues

    • SanDisk (SNDK): Q3 EPS of $1.59 beats by $0.27.
    • Revenue of $1.63B beats by $0.06B. Shares +1.7% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:45 PM
  • EBAY

    eBay Q4 guidance light, macro blamed; Amazon off in sympathy

    • EBAY expects Q4 revenue of $4.5B-$4.6B and EPS of $0.79-$0.81, below a consensus of $4.64B and $0.83. In a quote talking up eBay's Q3 numbers, CEO John Donahoe calls the macro environment "fairly lackluster." Back in July, European and Korean macro issues were blamed for eBay's below-consensus Q3 guidance.
    • Payments division (PayPal) growth remained strong in Q3: sales +19% Y/Y (to $1.62B) vs. +20% in Q2. Payment volume +25% (to $43.8B) vs. +24%, active accounts rose by 5M Q/Q to 137M (+17% Y/Y). Merchant services (non-eBay) transaction volume +30% Y/Y.
    • Marketplaces revenue +12% Y/Y (to $2.03B) vs. +10% in Q2; mobile provided a lift. GMV (exc. vehicles) +13%, even with Q2. U.S. GMV +15% vs. +16%, international +12% vs. +11%. Total listings topped 500M. Active users rose by 3.9M vs. 3.5M in Q2, +14% Y/Y and reaching 124M.
    • EBAY -4.2% AH. AMZN -1.2% in sympathy. CC at 5PM ET.
    • Q3 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:42 PM | 1 Comment
  • UFPI

    Universal Forest earnings triples to $0.71, beats on revenues

    • Universal Forest (NASDAQ:UFPI): Q3 EPS of $0.71 beats by $0.17.
    • Revenue of $651.78M (+22.2% Y/Y) beats by $26.01M. Shares +2.3% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:34 PM
  • SLM

    Sallie Mae beats by $0.01

    • Sallie Mae (NYSE:SLM): Q3 EPS of $0.60 beats by $0.01. Shares +2.6% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:29 PM
  • XLNX

    Xilinx slides on earnings

    • Xilinx (NASDAQ:XLNX): FQ2 GAAP EPS of $0.49.
    • Revenue of $599M (+10% Y/Y) beats by $10.72M. Shares -4.3% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:24 PM
  • CLB

    Core Labs records most profitable quarter, beats by $0.02

    • Core Labs (NYSE:CLB): Q3 EPS of $1.36 beats by $0.02.
    • Revenue of $273.2M (+11% Y/Y) beats by $5.99M. Shares +1.7% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:21 PM
  • IBM

    More on IBM: EPS guidance maintained, Asia-Pac sales nosedive

    • IBM is still guiding for 2013 EPS of at least $16.90 (consensus is at $16.89). Job cuts, $1.9B in buybacks (down from $3.6B in Q2), a lower tax rate (16% vs. 22% in Q2 and 24.6% a year earlier), and a 60 bps Y/Y increase in gross margin to 48% allowed Q3 EPS to beat estimates in spite of a $1B revenue miss.
    • Asia-Pac revenue -15% Y/Y, Americas -1%, EMEA +1%. Sales to BRIC countries fell 15% Y/Y., and sales to growth markets in general fell 9%.The numbers come shortly after Teradata warned of weak Asian sales.
    • Services revenue -4% Y/Y, same as Q2. Hardware is still ugly, -17% vs. -12%. Software +1% vs. +4%. Services backlog was $141B at quarter's end, flat Q/Q and +2% Y/Y.
    • IBM -5.2% AH. CC at 4:30PM ET.
    • Q3 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:20 PM | 14 Comments
  • IBM

    IBM beats by $0.03, misses on revenues

    • IBM (NYSE:IBM): Q3 EPS of $3.99 beats by $0.03.
    • Revenue of $23.7B (-4% Y/Y) misses by $1.07B. Shares -2.7% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:06 PM | 4 Comments
  • BHGE

    U.S. offshore drillers downgraded at BMO

    • BMO Capital downgrades the U.S. offshore drilling group to Underperform from Market Perform, expecting industry earnings to continue to slide due to lack of catalysts.
    • The firm upgrades Baker Hughes (BHI +1.8%) to Outperform and hikes its price target to $65 from $51, believing BHI's North American assumptions are too low given increased fund flows to the OFS sub-segment; Weatherford (WFT +1.7%) also was upgraded.
    • Among several downgrades, the firm cuts Diamond Offshore (DO +0.3%) to Underperform and cuts its price target to $64 from $70, seeing further earnings pressure in Brazil; also lowered were Atwood Oceanics (ATW -3.6%), Ensco (ESV +0.1%), Noble Corp. (NE +0.4%), Seadrill (SDRL -0.2%), Transocean (RIG +0.2%) and Rowan (RDC +0.5%).
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM | 11 Comments
  • ARCH

    Arch Coal sinks after Morgan Stanley downgrades on cheaper coal

    • Arch Coal (ACI -5.6%) is downgraded to Underweight from Equal Weight at Morgan Stanley, which expects even cheaper natural gas will knock down coal prices and ACI’s profits.
    • ACI is a thermal-heavy name with significant balance sheet leverage, making it vulnerable to prolonged depressed market conditions, the firm says.
    • Exelon (EXC -2.7%), which the firm also downgraded, is taking a hit; Consol Energy, which is also exposed to east coast coal is down too.
    • The firm sees two utilities benefiting from current trends; Calpine (CPN +0.8%) and Dominion Resources (D +2%), although the advantage may already be priced into D’s shares.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:38 PM | 7 Comments
  • ODP

    Office Depot and OfficeMax higher off of report FTC approval is coming

    • Office Depot (ODP +7.9%) and OfficeMax (OMX +9.1%) spike higher amid chatter the FTC is close to backing the merger of the office superstores.
    • Staples (SPLS +3.8%), which was already putting in some solid gains, also trekked higher off the same news.
    • The general consensus in the sector is that two major players is better than three.
    • OPD-OMX merger timeline
     
     
     
     
    | 3:23 PM
  • AA

    Alcoa says potline suspended at massive Saudi smelter

    • Alcoa (AA +1.5%) says the smelter run by the Ma'aden-Alcoa joint venture has temporarily shut down one of two potlines due to problems during ramp-up.
    • Repairs at the $10.8B smelter, which Alcoa owns and runs with Saudi Arabian Mining Co., could stretch well into next year, and AA now plans to accelerate the ramp-up of the second, unaffected line.
    • The outage comes at a crucial time for AA as it shifts primary aluminum output to the Middle East, where power costs are lower, and shuts higher-cost output in Europe and North America.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:04 PM | 5 Comments
  • CRM

    Enterprise cloud software stocks outperform following Veeva IPO

    • Salesforce (CRM +3.8%), NetSuite (N +2.3%), ServiceNow (NOW +4.4%), Marketo (MKTO +2.9%), and Cornerstone OnDemand (CSOD +2.2%) are all outperforming as Veeva Systems books enormous post-IPO gains that have left it trading at sky-high multiples.
    • The strong showing posted by Veeva, which provides cloud CRM, collaboration, and content management software for life sciences firms, highlights the strong interest growth investors continue to show in enterprise cloud software names. Until Veeva, there hadn't been a major IPO in the space since Workday's Oct. '12 debut.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:55 PM | 2 Comments
  • QUIK

    QuickLogic flies higher after launching sensor hub IC

    • QuickLogic's (QUIK +18.2%) new ArcticLink 3 S1 chip targets a fast-growing market for mobile device sensor hubs meant to interact with MEMS motion sensors (accelerometers, gyroscopes, etc.). (PRs: I, II)
    • The chipmaker asserts ArcticLink offers unmatched battery life, can offload sensor data processing from app processors, and (unlike rival solutions) can handle new algorithms for "always-on context awareness" for apps such as health/fitness monitoring, navigation, and augmented reality.
    • Apple's new M7 motion co-processor (found in the iPhone 5S) does some of the same things, and has fueled plenty of speculation about use cases. QuickLogic could sell ArcticLink to Android OEMs trying to keep pace. QuickLogic states (without naming a source) the sensor hub market is expected to see a 27% CAGR from 2013-2017, reaching annual shipments of 2.7B units.
    • Q3 results are due on Oct. 30.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:18 PM
  • LLTC

    Linear slides as FQ2 guidance overshadows FQ1 beat

    • Though Linear (LLTC -1.5%) beat FQ1 estimates, FQ2 sales are expected to be flat to down 4% Q/Q; that's worse than a consensus for 1% growth. The analog chipmaker blames seasonal order weakness and the potential for the government shutdown (about to end) to affect U.S. sales.
    • FQ1 book-to-bill was "slightly positive," and $7.9M was spent in the quarter on buybacks. Gross margin was 75.3%, +20 bps Y/Y. Automotive accounted for 19% of FQ1 bookings (a historical high), and Linear claims its 45.9% op. margin is unmatched within the industry. The company has been criticized in the past for prioritizing margins over growth.
    • Analog rival Semtech (SMTC -0.3%) is also underperforming, but other peers are following the market higher.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:58 PM
  • ZAHLY

    China Xiniya Fashion pops on momentum

    • China Xiniya Fashion shares (XNY +52.6%) pop on 42x 3-month average trading volume absent apparent news as momentum swells in low-P/E Chinese micro-caps.
    • Update: Zuaon Fashion (ZA +33.3%) is following suit.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:48 PM
  • CSCO

    More on MKM's Cisco downgrade and Juniper upgrade

    • MKM's Michael Genovese, who downgraded Cisco (CSCO -0.6%) to Neutral this morning, says checks indicate the emerging markets weakness the networking giant saw in FQ4 (the July quarter) has continued in FQ1, and that the government shutdown (now set to end) has hurt U.S. enterprise spending.
    • Genovese notes Cisco "tends to outperform when the y/y product order rate is accelerating," and notes this isn't the case following FQ4. Shares are up 23% since he upgraded Cisco to Buy a year ago.
    • At the same time, Genovese thinks rival Juniper (JNPR +4.1%), which has been upgraded to Buy, is about to see accelerating growth for its carrier ops (65% of revenue) thanks to improving core router/switch growth (as indicated by checks) and share gains for newer products such as the T4000 and PTX core router lines.
    • Cisco recently launched its NCS core router line to take on the PTX in a growing market for core routers that have more flexibility to handle diverse traffic loads than traditional hardware.
    • Juniper's service provider sales rose 7% Y/Y in Q2; enterprise sales rose 8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:41 PM | 1 Comment
  • LULU

    Bouncy day for Lululemon amid rumors

    • Shares of Lululemon (LULU -1.5%) show volatility amid chatter of a new short position from a major player.
    • Despite the ongoing battle with shorts, the retailer has bigger fish to fry.
    • For one, the issue of who the next CEO will be is unresolved, although top management thinks the current three-year strategic plan will remain in place no matter who is chosen.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:15 PM
  • OGXPY

    OGX completes 2-day double on speculation of $200M capital injection

    • After soaring 48% yesterday on speculation of an ouster of Eike Batista, shares of OGX Petroleo (OTCPK:OGXPY +56.3%) complete a 2-day double on local media reports that the company will secure a $200M capital injection from investors.
    • A local analyst opined, "For the first time, the market is seeing a solution for the company that doesn't involve judicial reorganization or bankruptcy." The new money would help OGX cover development costs at its oil fields until it begins production at a new offshore oil project by year-end, the analyst believes.
    • An obligation to consider: OGX missed a $45M bond coupon payment on Oct. 1, which has a 30-day grace period before OGX defaults.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:11 PM | 1 Comment
  • PRKR

    ParkerVision continues pre-verdict climb

    • ParkerVision (OTC:PRKR +10.6%) continues to climb in anticipation of a verdict in its patent infringement lawsuit against Qualcomm. A Jacksonville jury began deliberating yesterday afternoon.
    • PRKR is now up 22% from Friday's close.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:58 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Top 10 Gainers: GURE +44%. XNY +39%. GERN +33%. CNYD +28%. DHRM +28%. SEED +23%. ZA +22%. CNR +18%. AAP +16%. CCCR-OLD +16%.
    • Top 10 Losers: RVM -41%. OTC:PTSX -17%. HPJ -15%. EDN -15%. SWK -13%. PRIS -11%. CQB -11%. LBY -10%. ALTI -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM | 4 Comments
  • IVPAF

    Ivanhoe Mines reports "extraordinary" South Africa drilling results

    • Ivanhoe Mines (OTCQX:IVPAF +6.8%) surges in the wake of reports of "extraordinary" and "unprecedented" drilling results at its Platreef project in South Africa.
    • The company says the combined grade and thickness of the platinum group metals and base metals mineralization seen in the drilling "far exceeds" anything previously encountered at the Platreef project.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:39 PM
  • BK

    Custodial banks react to Mellon and Northern Trust reports

    • BNY Mellon (BK +0.6%) lags the market and its trust bank competitors State Street (STT +2.1%) and Northern Trust (NTRS +2.5%) after Q3 results (from BK and NTRS) this morning.
    • Mellon's adjusted net income of $706M was off about 2% from a year ago, with revenue off 7%. Assets under custody of $27.4T gained 4%. Foreign exchange fees of $160M fell 12%. Net interest revenue of $772M rose 3%, though NIM fell 4 basis points to 1.16%.
    • Northern Trust adjusted net income of $173.9M was off 2.7% Y/Y, with revenue up 8%. Assets under custody of $5.2T rose 10%. Noninterest income (77% of total) rose 11%. Trust, investment, and other servicing fees rose 8%. Foreign exchange income of $62.8M rose 43%. Net interest income of $244.8M fell 5% as net interest margin declined 7 basis points to 1.14%.
    • Previous: BNY Mellon deals with accusations of over-charging clients for FX activity.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:34 PM
  • AMX

    America Movil withdraws KPN offer, shares jump

    • Following weeks of tense negotiations, America Movil (AMX +5.9%) has decided to withdraw its bid for KPN (OTCPK:KKPNY -7.5%). AMX shares have spiked higher on the news.
    • Bloomberg reported earlier this month KPN wanted AMX, which already owns ~30% of the Dutch carrier, to raise its buyout offer above $10.7B to account for a tax ruling related to the pending sale of its German unit to Telefonica Deutschland.
    • AMX was said to be balking at the demand, arguing its offer already accounted for the tax ruling, and that the Dutch mobile market was seeing intensifying competition.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:33 PM
  • CLR

    Keystone more attractive if it would ship more U.S. oil, Hamm says

    • Continental Resources (CLR +3.2%) CEO Harold Hamm holds out the possibility that the Keystone XL pipeline could become a more attractive project if TransCanada (TRP +0.8%) would agree to carry a greater percentage of domestic U.S. oil instead of Canadian crude, and says CLR would be open to talks to help the project achieve that aim.
    • The 800K bbl/day pipeline is planned to take only 100K bbl/day of oil from the Bakken oil fields; CLR has a contract for to take ~35K bbl/day of its Bakken oil.
    • Hamm reiterates that if TRP sticks to its current projections of carrying 700K bbl/day oil sands petroleum the pipeline is not crucial for his company.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:26 PM | 3 Comments
  • GLUU

    Canaccord lifts Glu Mobile PT, pleased with improving game data

    • Canaccord's Michael Graham has raised his Glu Mobile (GLUU +2.6%) PT to $4 from $3, and thinks improving game metrics "point to probable upside" for his Q3 bookings estimate.
    • Canaccord's data points to "fairly stable metrics" for older Glu titles in Q3, and "a couple weeks of great performance" for Deer Hunter 2014, which raced to the top of App Store download charts and has already provided a lift to Glu shares.
    • Glu's Q3 report arrives on Oct. 30.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:25 PM
  • SEED

    Chinese agricultural biotechnology companies spike on new potash bill

    • Origin Agritech  (SEED +23.9%) and Agria (GRO +15.5%) shares spike after reports surface that China's Ministry of Agriculture has approved a new potash bill which is being perceived as a boon for agricultural biotech companies.
    • Tianli Agritech (OINK +3.4%) is up as well but lagging the pack.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:20 PM
  • SNCAF

    SNC-Lavalin slashes 2013 earnings outlook

    • SNC-Lavalin (OTCPK:SNCAF -5.1%) takes an axe to its 2013 earnings view to C$10M-C$50M from its most recent guidance for C$220M-C$235M, citing higher project costs, additional charges related to a reorganization in Europe and further softness in commodity markets.
    • SNC, which has faced corruption allegations and probes into alleged improper payments linked to some international projects, posted an unexpected Q2 loss on writedowns at two North African projects, which sparked concerns about potential further charges.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:55 AM
  • LNG

    Cheniere Energy target lifted to $47 at Deutsche Bank

    • Cheniere Energy's (LNG +2.9%) price target is raised to $47 from $39 at Deutsche Bank, which also maintains a Buy rating on the stock, based on higher EBITDA expected from the underlying Cheniere Energy Partners (NYSEMKT:CQP) MLP, the inclusion of Corpus Christi at a valuation of ~$470M ($2/share) and the inclusion of Trains 5 and 6 at ~$450M ($2/share).
    • At CQP, the firm says the inclusion of projected CMI EBITDA of $145M for Trains 1-4 continues to appear conservative based on its macro view of worldwide liquefied natural gas fundamentals and additional capacity at Sabine Pass and Corpus Christi will add to volume potential.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:39 AM | 2 Comments
  • AIG

    Multi-year high for AIG

    • With the markets in general moving higher, AIG (AIG +2.1%) is also being boosted by a big quarter for mortgage insurer MGIC Investment and the successful IPO of Springleaf Financial.
    • AIG has its own mortgage insurance unit - United Guaranty - which contributed $73M towards the company's $1.7B In operating income last quarter.
    • AIG's TARP warrants are ahead 2.4% to $19.90, still 2% below the 52-week high. To review: These are struck at $45 and expire in 2021 (and will be adjusted for dividends). The current stock price is $51.17.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:38 AM | 5 Comments
  • ERN

    Camac Energy says preliminary Nigeria well results top expectations

    • Camac Energy (CAK +15.2%) says preliminary results show its deepwater Oyo-7 development probe off Nigeria has hit more oil and less gas pay than expected.
    • The well encountered net oil pay of 115 feet and net gas pay of 93 feet in the gas cap from the currently producing Pliocene reservoir, with excellent reservoir quality.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:24 AM
  • OMF

    Subprime lender surges after IPO

    • Springleaf Holdings (NYSE:LEAF) gains 12% in early trades after pricing its upsized IPO (from 20M to 21M shares) at $16 per share.
    • Springleaf is worth keeping an eye on given the last few years - it's a subprime consumer lender (average loan balance of $3.5K, interest rate 20%-36%) and joint venture between AIG and Fortress Investment (NYSE:FIG). Earlier this year, the company successfully issued a rare securitization of subprime consumer loans.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:00 AM | 3 Comments
  • PXD

    Pioneer Natural Resources powers past $200

    • Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD +5%) gaps up to a new 52-week high as Susquehanna raises its price target for PXD to $180 from $170, noting that the company’s operations in the northern and central parts of Midland Wolfcamp in Texas are expected to be a strong catalyst for the stock next year.
    • Jim Cramer sees the stock hitting $300: "This stock is not nearly done.. the good news about the Permian is that we've already got the pipe laid."
    • Michael Fitzsimmons says shares could easily double over the next three years as drilling results in the Spraberry/Wolfcamp play unlock the value of PXD's 800K-plus acreage position.
    • Permian/Wolfcamp stocks are following PXD's lead: DVN +2.4%, EOG +2.7%, AREX +2.6%, HK +3.4%, SWN +1.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:59 AM | 5 Comments
  • PTLA

    Portola Pharmaceuticals sinks on news of public offering

    • Portola Pharmaceuticals (PTLA -7.1%) falls sharply after announcing a $100M public offering.
    • The deal will reportedly include shares from selling stockholders.
    • The company intends to use a portion of the proceeds to "support the pursuit of an accelerated approval process for Andexanet alfa." (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:58 AM
  • CELG

    Receptos rallies on Celgene, Teva buyout rumors

    • Receptos (RCPT +20.3%) soars after Calcalist says Celgene (NASDAQ:CELG) and Teva (NYSE:TEVA) are bidding for the company.
    • Bids are reportedly in the $700-800M range.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:50 AM
  • VEEV

    Veeva Systems soars following IPO

    • After pricing its 13M-share IPO at $20 yesterday, Veeva (NYSE:VEEV) opened at $38 and is currently at $36.99, up 85%. That gives the provider of cloud software for life sciences firm a market cap of $4.53B.
    • Even if Veeva's revenue growth in the second half of fiscal 2014 (ends Jan. '14) matches the 71% seen in the first half, shares would still be trading at more than 20x FY14 sales.
    • S-1, IPO preview
     
     
     
     
    | 10:48 AM | 4 Comments
  • RDN

    Mortgage insurers soar after MGIC results

    • Radian (RDN +5.9%), Genworth (GNW +2.9%), and MGIC Investment (MTG +16.4%) following its surprisingly profitable Q3.
    • The housing bust continues to fade with remaining risk in force on insurance written from 2005-2008 now at about $18B, and risk in force on insurance written since 2009 at about $16B (Q3 portfolio supplement). Delinquencies on policies written from 2005-2008 range  from 9%-17%, while those on policies written since the bust are mostly less than 1%.
    • LTV ratios above 97% on policies written since 2009 are nil vs. as high as 44% during the boom years.
    • The earnings call continues - live on Seeking Alpha. The main theme: "Congrats on the great quarter."
     
     
     
     
    | 10:46 AM
  • RVM

    Revett Minerals crushed after update on Troy mine development

    • Revett Minerals (RVM -44.1%) shares are cut nearly in half after the company says it will not resume mining operations using the Lower Quartzite haulage route at the Troy mine in Montana and instead will construct a new development decline to the North C Bed and I-Bed deposits in the Lower Revett Formation.
    • RVM believes it can construct the new decline through previously unmined areas without incurring the structural issues that have hampered its ability to return to production since operations at Troy were suspended in December.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:42 AM | 2 Comments
  • TSLA

    SolarCity prices stock, convertible debt offerings

    • SolarCity (SCTY +2.9%) is selling 3.4M shares at $46.54 (3% below current levels), and $200M worth of convertible senior notes due 2018. The debt offering was upsized from $125M yesterday. Net proceeds from the offerings are expected to total $344.8M-$396.6M, depending on the extent to which underwriter options are exercised. (PR)
    • The convertible notes carry an interest rate of 2.75%, and a conversion price of $61.67 (30% above current levels).
    • The offerings are the latest in a string of financing moves (I, II, III) carried out by SolarCity, as the company makes an all-out push to ramp its solar installations.

    A roundup of tech ratings changes

    • Intel (INTC +0.3%) has been upgraded to Buy by B. Riley following its Q3 beat and light Q4 revenue guidance.

    • Vimpelcom (VIP +3.9%) has been upgraded to Overweight by Morgan Stanley.

    • Ellie Mae (ELLI -6.5%) has been cut to Market Perform by JMP.
    • Super Micro (SMCI -2.7%) has been cut to Hold by Stifel.

  • UBSFY

    Ubisoft plummets after delaying game releases, slashing guidance

    • Ubisoft (OTCPK:UBSFY) shares are down 26.4% in Paris trading after the game developer announces that its Watch Dogs and The Crew releases will be delayed until 2014. As a result, the company slashed its full-year revenue outlook by more than €400m to €0.995B-€1.04B and expects an operating loss on the year of €40M-€70M (vs. previous expectations of operating profit of €110M-€125M).
    • CEO Yves Guillemot said the "tough decision" to delay the titles came from the necessity to improve the games' quality and maximize their chances to become blockbusters.
    • The company now expects operating income of at least €150M in FY2014 and €200M in FY2015.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:44 AM

  • RTIX

    RTI Surgical falls after warning on Q3 revenue

    • RTI Surgical (NASDAQ:RTIX) slides 5% premarket after announcing preliminary Q3 revenues of $54.7M versus previous guidance of $59-61M.
    • The company blames the shortfall on "uncertainties surrounding when the FDA would provide a [warning letter] close-out, a slower than expected ramp in [the] new direct surgical specialties business, lower than expected volumes in [the] spine business, and lower than projected [international] revenues."
    • RTIX also says it has entered into a distribution deal with Medtronic (NYSE:MDT) for the "processing [of] allograft implants for use in spinal surgeries." Effectively, the new agreement extends the companies' existing agreement which expires next year. (PR)

  • ABT

    Abbott affirms EPS outlook, lifts dividend, but results hit by pediatric recall

    • "We continued to have strong earnings performance, in spite of a supplier recall that impacted our International Nutrition business," Abbott Lab's (NYSE:ABT) Miles White notes, referring to the supplier recall in August that hit the company's international pediatrics business.
    • Worldwide sales rose 4.3% for Q3 ex-currency impact and 2% on a reported basis. The supplier recall reduced sales by an estimated 2%.
    • Adjusted operating margin rose 210 bps Y/Y.
    • On a segment-by-segment basis (currency neutral): Nutrition sales +3.4%; Diagnostics +10.5% (stronger than expected here, reflecting double-digit growth in Molecular and Point of Care Diagnostics, as well as high single-digit growth in the Core Laboratory business); Established Pharmaceuticals +0.6% (-2.9% reported); Medical Devices +3.9%.
    • Quarterly dividend increased 57% to $0.22/share.
    • FY13 outlook affirmed at $1.98-2.04/share. Consensus is $2/share. (PR)
    • ABT +1.6% premarket.
